questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is false about herd immunity?

options.a: It refers to group protection beyond what is afforded by the protection of immunized
options.b: Vaccination allows the possibility of 100% herd immunity against a disease
options.c: It is affected by presence and distribution of alternative animal hosts
options.d: It doesn’t protect the individual in the case of tetanus

questions.explanation:
It is not possible to achieve 100% herd immunity against a certain disease but studies have shown 
this is not necessary for disease control. 154 
Sold by @itachibot Herd structure is never constant. It is subject to constant variation because of new births, deaths 
and population mobility. An ongoing immunization programme will keep up the herd immunity at 
a very high level.

questions.question: Question 2: Herd immunity threshold does not vary with which of the following?

options.b: Efficacy of the vaccine for the disease
options.c: Number of vaccines for the disease

questions.explanation:
Herd immunity threshold does not vary with the number of vaccines for the disease. It varies only 
due to the virulence of the disease, efficacy of the vaccine and contact parameter for the 
population.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is false about normal human immunoglobulin (NHIG)?

options.a: All live vaccines can be given simultaneously with NHIG.
options.b: They are used against measles and hepatitis A.
options.c: There should be a low IgA concentration in NHIG preparations.
options.d: Each NHIG fraction is obtained from at least 1,000 donors.

questions.explanation:
Live vaccines should generally be avoided for 12 weeks following an injection of normal human 
immunoglobulin (Ig). If a live vaccine has already been administered, the injection of normal 
human Ig should be delayed for 2 weeks. NHIG is an antibody-rich fraction that is usually obtained from a pool of at least 1,000 donors. 
AN NHIG preparation must contain at least 90% intact IgG and minimal IgG aggregates with low 
IgA concentration. NHIG is commonly used to prevent measles and hepatitis A infections. Specific human immunoglobulins are made from the plasma of patients who have recently 
recovered from an infection or are obtained from individuals who have been immunized against a 
specific infection. These preparations have a high antibody content against an individual infection 
and provide immediate protection.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is false about specific human immunoglobulins?
questions.explanation:
Specific human immunoglobulins or hyperimmune human Igs are obtained from selected donors 
that have high titres of the antibodies to the disease like those who have recovered from the 
disease. It is commonly used in prophylaxis of chickenpox in highly susceptible individuals and in 
post-exposure prophylaxis of hepatitis B.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following is not true about secondary booster immune response in comparison 
with primary response?

options.a: Antibody elicited tends to have a greater avidity to bind to the antigen
options.b: Antibody response is at a higher level
options.c: Antibody response is maintained for a longer period of time

questions.explanation:
Production of antibodies is faster in secondary booster response. Primary response is the immune response developed when an antigen is administered for the first 
time to a person who has never been exposed to it. There is a latent period of 3-10 days before 
antibodies appear in the blood. Secondary booster response is the immune response elicited by a booster dose. In comparison to a 
primary immune response, it has a shorter latent period, faster production of antibodies, and 155 
Sold by @itachibot an abundance of antibodies. The antibody response is maintained at higher levels for a longer 
period of time, and the antibody elicited tends to have a greater avidity or capacity to bind to the 
antigen.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is false about live vaccines?

options.a: Simultaneous administration of two live vaccines should be done in the same syringe
options.b: Two live vaccines can be administered simultaneously
options.c: Immuno-compromised state poses a contraindication to live vaccines
options.d: Live vaccines contain both major and minor antigens

questions.explanation:
Simultaneous administration of vaccines is defined as administering more than one vaccine on the 
same clinic day, at different anatomic sites. They are not combined in the same syringe. Simultaneous administration of the most widely used live and inactivated vaccines does not result 
in decreased antibody responses or increased rates of adverse reaction. However, in children with 
functional or anatomic asplenia pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV13) and Menactra brand 
meningococcal conjugate vaccines should not be administered at the same visit; separate these 
vaccines by at least 4 weeks. Advantages of simultaneous administration of vaccines: • The organisms multiply in the host and thus, the antigenic dose is larger than what is injected. • They have all the major and minor antigenic components. Live vaccines should not be administered to those with an immunocompromised state, since they 
may cause severe systemic disease by way of viremia/bacteriemia. Note: If live vaccines are not given simultaneously, they must be spaced as follows- • The administration of two live parenteral vaccines or live intranasal influenza vaccines must be 
separated by at least 4 weeks (28 days). • If two live vaccines are given less than 4 weeks apart, the second vaccine should be repeated in 
four weeks. This is because the live vaccine given first can interfere with the second vaccine, and 
the person may not develop active immunity to the second vaccine.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is not a killed vaccine?
questions.explanation: Yellow fever vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine. Injectable polio vaccine (Salk vaccine), pertussis vaccine, and rabies vaccine are killed vaccines.

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to administration of inactivated or 
killed vaccines?
questions.explanation:
The only absolute contraindication to administration of an inactivated or killed vaccine is severe 
local or general reaction to a previous dose of the vaccine. Inactivated or killed vaccines are made from growing cultures of the organism and then 
inactivating them with heat or chemicals.They activate the channels of active immunity after 
injection and are less efficacious than live vaccines. Multiple doses or booster doses are usually 
required to produce an adequate antibody response. 156 
Sold by @itachibot Killed vaccines can be given to immune-compromised individuals and in pregnancy as the 
infective agent is inactivated and cannot grow. Egg allergy is not an absolute contraindication to the administration of an inactivated or killed 
vaccine.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following are live vaccines?
questions.explanation: Yellow fever vaccine and Sabin vaccine (oral polio vaccine) are live vaccines. HBV and HPV vaccines are recombinant vaccines. Tetanus vaccine is a toxoid vaccine.

questions.question: Question 10: What should be the minimum interval between the administration of two live vaccines?
questions.explanation:
The minimum interval between the administration of two live vaccines is 4 weeks. This is because decreasing the interval between two doses may interfere with the antibody 
response and protection. Thus, live vaccines can either be given on the same day according to the 
schedule or 4 weeks apart. Note: In Park 27th ed. the minimum interval between two live vaccines is given as 3 weeks. 
However, several other standard sources including CDC and UNDP suggested an interval of 4 
weeks. When both are given in options, it is recommended to mark 4 weeks as the correct answer.

questions.question:
Question 11: In which of the following diseases should active and passive immunisation not be done 
together?
questions.explanation:
Active and passive immunization should not be done together for measles as the vaccine used is a 
live vaccine. Live vaccines should generally be avoided for 12 weeks following an injection of normal human 
immunoglobulin (Ig). If a live vaccine has already been administered, the injection of normal 
human Ig should be delayed for 2 weeks. Note: In the case of measles alone, the recommended interval between administration of Measles 
immunoglobulins and Live measles vaccine is about 6 months in a non-immunocompromised 
individual and 8 months in an immunocompromised individual.

questions.question: Question 12: What is the main drawback of polysaccharide-based vaccines?

options.a: They cause severe pain at the injection site
options.b: The immune responses elicited are serotype specific
options.c: It cannot be conjugated with proteins to enhance immunogenicity
options.d: The rate of adverse reactions is very high

questions.explanation:
Polysaccharide-based vaccines stimulate an antibody response against the surface polysaccharide 
of the pathogenic-capsulated bacteria. The polysaccharide structure varies not only between 
bacteria of different species but also between different strains within a single species. Thus, a 
limitation of these vaccines is that the immune responses are serotype-specific. 157 
Sold by @itachibot If these vaccines are conjugated with proteins, they are given the capability of eliciting a stronger 
immune response. Multivalent formulations of both polysaccharide-based vaccines and 
conjugated vaccines are required to achieve protection against multiple serotypes.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is a subunit vaccine?
questions.explanation:
Hepatitis B vaccine is an example of a subunit vaccine made using HBsAg. Subunit vaccines are produced from macromolecules derived from immunogenic components of 
organisms by recombinant DNA technology. E.g., HPV vaccine (uses L1 major capsid protein) and 
hepatitis B vaccine (uses HBsAg). BCG is a live attenuated vaccine, IPV is an inactivated vaccine and DPT has diphtheria and 
tetanus toxoids and a killed pertussis component.

questions.question:
Question 14: You are a medical officer conducting an ANC camp in a rural village near Hubli, Karnataka. 
Which of the following vaccines would you not administer to a pregnant woman?
questions.explanation:
Yellow fever vaccines are contraindicated in pregnancy in non-endemic areas. It is a live 
vaccine and most live vaccines are contraindicated in pregnancy unless the risk of infection is 
much greater than the risk of harm to the fetus. Note: Yellow fever vaccine is not an absolute contraindication as it is administered in certain 
endemic areas and in outbreaks

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient is diagnosed to have an allergy to eggs. Administration of which of the following 
vaccines is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.explanation: Influenza and yellow fever vaccines are contraindicated in patients having an allergy to eggs.

questions.question:
Question 16: A newborn baby is HIV + and symptomatic. Which of the following vaccines must not be 
given to her?
questions.explanation:
BCG vaccine must not be administrated to HIV-infected infants who are symptomatic despite the 
presence of high TB prevalence. Since BCG is a live vaccine, it significantly increases the risk of 
disseminated TB in a symptomatic HIV+ infant. However, asymptomatic infants who are HIV+ can be given BCG, provided the risk of contracting 
TB is high in that region. In areas of low TB prevalence or risk, the BCG vaccine is avoided. 158 
Sold by @itachibot WHO recommendations for administering live vaccines in symptomatic HIV+ patients: • Measles vaccine (or MMR) is allowed even in the symptomatic stage of HIV infection (except in 
the terminal phase), so as to prevent serious and life-threatening wild measles virus disease. Avoid 
MMR only if CD4+ < 15% (severely immunocompromised). • IPV is an inactivated vaccine and must be used as an alternative to OPV.

questions.question:
Question 17: Which of the following side effects is most likely to develop in a newborn, following BCG 
vaccination?
questions.explanation:
Ulceration is the most common side effect post BCG vaccination. Following vaccination, the local tissue response begins in 2-3 weeks and results in scar formation 
and healing within 3 months. Side effects most commonly seen include ulceration at the 
vaccination site and regional lymphadenitis. Some vaccine strains may also rarely cause 
osteomyelitis. In immunocompromised states, disseminated BCG infection can occur. The image below shows the typical adverse effcts seen following BCG vaccination: • Regional lymphadenopathy • Suppurative lymphadenopathy with fistula • Ulcer at injection site • Cold abscess at inject site 159 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: A child who had recently received the BCG vaccine comes to you with complaints of fever, 
pain and swelling at the injection site. You suspect a localised abscess formation. Which of 
the following steps should be avoided in the treatment of this child?

options.b: Incision and application of INH powder
options.d: Incision and application of PAS powder

questions.explanation:
There is no need for systemic treatment with INH in case of a local abscess formation after BCG 
vaccination. If there is a local abscess formation following BCG vaccination, it should be treated by aspiration. 
If it does not clear, then it should be incised and INH or PAS powder should be applied daily to 
the site. The patient should be assured of the harmless nature of the lesion.

questions.question:
Question 19: A complete blood count was obtained for a patient after they were administered vaccine X. 
The report is shown below. Which of the following options is most likely to be vaccine X?
questions.explanation:
The lab report shows a low platelet count or thrombocytopenia. This is a possible adverse effect of 
the MMR vaccine.

questions.question:
Question 20: 152 
Sold by @itachibot Persistent inconsolable crying can be a result of administration of which of the following 
vaccines?
questions.explanation:
Persistent inconsolable crying is usually seen after DPT vaccine. It is mostly attributed to the 
pertussis fraction of the vaccine. It usually lasts for 3 hours and settles after a day or so. Other adverse effects of the DTP vaccine 
include neurologic effects like encephalitis and encephalopathies.

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following statements is false about the DPT vaccine?

options.a: Adult preparation contains a lower dose of diphtheria than the pediatric version
options.b: Whole killed bacteria of Bordetella pertussis has an adjuvant effect
options.c: The whole-cell killed B. pertussis component is encephalogenic
options.d: Presence of H. influenzae type b component increases its immunogenicity

questions.explanation:
160 
Sold by @itachibot H. influenzae type b (Hib) is not a component of the DPT vaccine and hence cannot affect 
its immunogenicity. It is a component of the pentavalent vaccine. The DPT vaccine is made up of diphtheria, pertussis and tetanus vaccines. The pertussis 
component in DPT vaccine enhances the potency of the diphtheria toxoid. Both whole-cell killed 
B. pertussis and acellular pertussis component have this adjuvant effect. The only difference is 
that whole-cell killed B. pertussis is encephalitogenic and immunity is short-lasting, while the 
acellular pertussis component (DTaP) is devoid of neurological complications. There are two types of DPT vaccines - plain and adsorbed. Adsorption is usually carried out on a 
mineral carrier like aluminium phosphate or hydroxide. Adsorbed vaccines are more 
immunogenic and recommended by WHO for national vaccination programmes.

questions.question:
Question 22: A worried mother brings her baby to your PHC saying her child has gone limp. She mentions 
the child had recently been given some oral drops as part of a mass vaccination campaign. 
Which of the following is the most likely cause of the baby's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of paralysis and the likely cause is vaccine-associated paralytic 
poliomyelitis following OPV administration. This is a rare side effect of OPV. Acute-onset flaccid paralysis occurs within 4 to 30 days of receipt 
of the vaccine in these cases or within 4 to 75 days after contact with a vaccine recipient.

questions.question:
Question 23: A patient presents with complaints of severe aching pain and weakness in his left arm and 
shoulder. He mentions he had recently been administered a vaccine in his left arm, but he 
does not remember the name of the vaccine. Which of the following could be the most 
common cause of his symptoms?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of brachial neuritis which is a known complication of the tetanus 
vaccine. Brachial neuritis is a dysfunction of nerves supplying the arm and shoulder without the 
involvement of the rest of the nervous system. It presents with a deep, steady, severe aching pain 
in the shoulder and arm followed by weakness and wasting in arm and shoulder muscles. Sensory 
loss may also be present. It is treated symptomatically by analgesics. 161 
Sold by @itachibot Vaccine Production and Storage
